Literature Review: The life cycle of mRNAs in single cells has been a subject of intense research in recent years, with significant advances in single-molecule imaging techniques. These approaches have enabled researchers to study the lives of mRNAs with unprecedented spatial and temporal detail, moving beyond simple observation of specific events to understanding the regulation of mRNA metabolism. This review aims to summarize the current state of knowledge on the life cycle of mRNAs in single cells, with a focus on the regulation of transcription, splicing, localization, translation, and decay.
